abstractText: Cell-free massive multiple-input multiple-output (CF mMIMO) systems are characterized by having many more access points (APs) than user equipments (UEs). A key challenge is to determine which APs should serve which UEs. Previous work has tackled this combinatorial problem heuristically. This paper proposes a sparse large-scale fading decoding (LSFD) design for CF mMIMO to jointly optimize the association and LSFD. We formulate a group sparsity problem and then solve it using a proximal algorithm with block-coordinate descent. Numerical results show that sparse LSFD achieves almost the same spectral efficiency as optimal LSFD, thus achieving a higher energy efficiency since the processing and signaling are reduced.

Sparse Large-Scale Fading Decoding in
Cell-Free Massive MIMO Systems Shuaifei Chen∗,⋆, Jiayi Zhang∗,⋆, Emil Björnson†, Özlem Tuğfe Demir†, and Bo Ai⋆,‡ ∗School of Electronic and Information Engineering, Beijing Jiaotong University, Beijing 100044, China

Abstract—Cell-free massive multiple-input multiple-output (CF mMIMO) systems are characterized by having many more access points (APs) than user equipments (UEs). A key challenge is to determine which APs should serve which UEs. Previous work has tackled this combinatorial problem heuristically. This paper proposes a sparse large-scale fading decoding (LSFD) design for CF mMIMO to jointly optimize the association and LSFD. We formulate a group sparsity problem and then solve it using a proximal algorithm with block-coordinate descent. Numerical results show that sparse LSFD achieves almost the same spectral efficiency as optimal LSFD, thus achieving a higher energy efficiency since the processing and signaling are reduced.
Index Terms—Cell-free massive MIMO, large-scale fading decoding, sparse optimization.
I. INTRODUCTION
The sixth-generation (6G) communications are expected to achieve 100× spectral efficiency (SE) and energy efficiency (EE) gains over the fifth-generation networks [1]. This requires a denser network infrastructure and cell-free (CF) operation that shifts the communication network from cell-centric to user-centric, to provide ubiquitous coverage, improved network throughput, and reduced energy consumption [2]–[4].
User-centric CF massive multiple-input multiple-output (mMIMO) is a promising paradigm for increasing the average and worst-case data rates in 6G networks [5]. In CF mMIMO, a large number of distributed access points (APs), coordinated by a central processing unit (CPU), serve the user equipments (UEs) by coherent joint transmission and reception, as illustrated in Fig. 1. Due to the UE-AP-CPU architecture, the signal processing tasks can be distributed between the APs and the CPU in different ways [6], [7]. Especially, [6] applied large-scale fading decoding (LSFD), which is a two-stage decoding procedure where all APs first compute soft estimates of the data signal from all UEs and then deliver them to the CPU for final decoding. Although this approach achieves a good compromise between SE and computational complexity compared to fully centralized processing [5], it might not be energy efficient in a large network in its original form. It is unnecessary for an AP to waste power and computational resources on UEs with weak channels to it [8]. The geometry induces a sparse structure on the practically meaningful APUE associations. Prior work has suggested associating each UE with a subset of APs (typically in a heuristic non-SEoptimizing manner [9]) in advance and then excluding APs not serving this UE when computing the LSFD vector [6],
This work was supported in part by the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities under Grant 2021YJS001 and in part by the FFL18-0277 grant from the Swedish Foundation for Strategic Research.
[9]. However, treating the AP-UE association as a separate combinatorial problem from the LSFD design, which is used to maximize the SE [6], is suboptimal. That motivates us to take the association as a part of the LSFD design and exploit sparsity methods to jointly solve the association problem.
Sparse optimization has attracted extensive research interest in the fields of signal processing, image processing, and computer vision [10]. Specific to communications, sparse optimization was applied for activity detection [11], random access [12], and node sleeping [13]. Especially, [13] turned off some “unnecessary” APs in a CF mMIMO network by formulating a sparse reconstruction problem. Similarly, in [4], binary programming is utilized to activate only the minimal subsets of APs for each UE to minimize the end-to-end network power consumption. Inspired by these approaches, we formulate a new sparse optimization problem that minimizes the mean-squared-error (MSE), to enforce sparsity on the LSFD coefficients. The major contributions are as follows:
• We propose the new sparse LSFD (S-LSFD) design where
joint AP-UE association and LSFD is achieved by formulating a sparsity-inducing MSE-minimizing problem to force small LSFD coefficients to zero. • We solve the sparsity problem by developing a proximal
algorithm with block-coordinate descent (BCD) that is tailored to our problem. • We compare the proposed S-LSFD, the optimal LSFD
(O-LSFD) [6], and the partial LSFD (P-LSFD) [6] with the separate association algorithm in [9], considering the SE and EE and different combining schemes.

sections.heading: II. CF MMIMO SYSTEM MODEL
sections.text: We consider a CF mMIMO system consisting of K singleantenna UEs and L geographically distributed APs, each equipped with N antennas. As illustrated in Fig. 1, we adopt the user-centric CF architecture, where each UE is served by a subset of APs based on the UE-dependent channel quality and service requirement. All APs are connected via fronthaul connections to a CPU, which is responsible for coordinating and processing the signals of all UEs. The AP-UE association is optimized in Section III. For now, we let Dl⊂{1, . . . ,K} denote the subset of UEs served by AP l andMk⊂{1, . . . , L} denote the subset of APs serving UE k.

sections.heading: A. Channel Model
sections.text: We denote by hkl ∈ CN the channel between AP l and UE k and assume that these channels are constant in timefrequency coherence blocks of τc channel uses [14]. We assume spatially correlated Rayleigh fading, which implies that in each block hkl takes an independent realization according to the distribution hkl ∼ NC(0,Rkl), (1) where Rkl ∈ CN×N is the spatial correlation matrix, and βkl ∆ = tr(Rkl)/N is the large-scale fading coefficient that describes pathloss and shadowing. We assume that AP l knows the correlation matrices {Rkl : k = 1, . . . ,K} to all UEs since the correlation matrices represent the long-term channel statistics, and, thus, can be accurately estimated from the received signals [14]. We consider the uplink operation, where each block dedicates τp channel uses for pilots and the remaining τc − τp channel uses for payload data.

IV. NUMERICAL RESULTS
In this section, we evaluate the performance of the proposed S-LSFD design in Section III and validate the algorithm convergence by comparing it to CVX [20]. We consider a setup with K = 20 UEs that are independently and uniformly dropped in a 0.5× 0.5 km2 area. The wrap-around technique is used to approximate an infinitely large network. We use the 3GPP Urban Microcell model to compute the large-scale propagation conditions, such as pathloss and shadow fading. The SE results with L-MMSE combining are obtained from Monte Carlo simulations while the results with MR combining are analytically computed by [9, Cor. 2]. Pilot assignment is performed with the scheme from [9]. The main system parameters are given in Table I and originate from [7], [16].
We consider two deployment setups: a) L = 40, N = 4 and b) L = 160, N = 1. Both setups have the total number of antennas LN = 160. To highlight the performance improvements of our joint AP-UE association and LSFD, we consider two benchmarks: the first one is the O-LSFD in (12) where all APs serve all UEs, and the second one applies the heuristic AP-UE association scheme from [9] followed by PLSFD. The latter is referred to as “P-LSFD” in this section.
In Fig. 2 and Fig. 3, we set the vertical scale intervals to emphasize how small/large the gaps are between the curves.
In Fig. 2, we first evaluate the average SE when the S-LSFD is used and we vary the regularization parameters λ and γ. The first observation is that both the average SE with L-MMSE combining and MR combining decreases as λ increases since the number of serving APs per UE decreases. These SE results are only slightly below the O-LSFD but above the P-LSFD (for small values of λ that let each UE be served by its most essential APs). The SE with MR combining drops more markedly than the SE with L-MMSE combining, since the interference suppression makes L-MMSE more robust to a reduction in the number of serving APs. This feature of L-MMSE also reflects on the SE gaps between the two AP deployment setups, where the L-MMSE case (between Fig. 2(a) and (b)) has more narrow gaps than the MR case (between Fig. 2(c) and (d)). Moreover, we notice that the multi-antenna AP setup outperforms the single-antenna AP setup in the L-MMSE case while it is the opposite in the MR case. The reason is that in the L-MMSE case, the interference suppression gain enabled by multiple antennas is more beneficial the macro diversity gain brought by having more APs. In contrast, the macro diversity gain dominates in the MR case, which relies on it for avoiding interference. When comparing the SE with different γ, we notice the average SE loss compared to O-LSFD grows when γ increases for a similar reason as for λ.
Fig. 3 shows the average EE of our S-LSFD design. It is clear that although our S-LSFD slightly reduces the SE, it significantly increases the EE compared to the O-LSFD where all APs serve all UEs. Our joint design also outperform PLSFD where the AP-UE association and LSFD are performed separately. We notice that the setup L = 40, N = 4 gives higher EE than the setup L = 160, N = 1 since it consumes
10-4 10-3 10-2 10-1

more power to have many APs (see (15)). Another observation is that the EE gaps between L-MMSE and MR is larger with multi-antenna APs (between Fig. 3(a) and (c)) than with single-antenna APs (between Fig. 3(b) and (d)) thanks to the interference suppression. The average EE is unimodal with respect to λ in Fig. 3(b), (c), and (d), which implies that there exist a value of λ that provides maximum average EE.
The convergence of our proposed proximal algorithm is validated by checking the following two metrics: the accuracy ∆f/f∗ and the elapsed time. The accuracy is defined as the function value difference ∆f = f − f∗ normalized by the “optimal” function value f∗ obtained by CVX, which is shown in Fig. 4. The elapsed times for convergence with different sparsity parameters are given in Table II, where the shadowed results correspond to CVX. Fig. 4 validates the correctness of our algorithm by showing the accuracy of 10−4. It can be seen in Fig. 4 that the proximal algorithm converges faster with a larger λ. The results in Table II indicate the effectiveness of our algorithm where the elapsed time of our algorithm is much less than that of CVX, especially when λ and γ are small.

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSION
sections.text:
We proposed a new mechanism for joint AP-UE association and LSFD design for CF mMIMO by formulating a group sparsity problem. We solved the problem by a proximal
algorithm with BCD to intentionally turn off some APs and limit the number of UEs served by each of the remaining active APs. Numerical results showed that, compared to the O-LSFD and P-LSFD, the proposed S-LSFD gives a better association and more flexibility on the sparsity parameters, and, thus, achieves significant EE improvements with relatively small SE loss, especially when using L-MMSE combining with multiantenna APs. Maximum EE could be achieved by tuning λ.

title: Sparse Large-Scale Fading Decoding in Cell-Free Massive MIMO Systems
